awd_titl_txt: Developing 2+2+2 Pathways in Agribusiness to Meet the Needs of California's Agriculture Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
Madera Community College Center, as part of Reedley College, will undertake "Developing 2+2+2 Pathways in Agribusiness to Meet the Needs of California's Agriculture Industry". This project will develop new pathways and credentials in agribusiness education to train the next generation of farmers, leaders, and professionals. The project also aims to increase workplace diversity by recruiting under-represented students into agriculture. The State of California ranks first in the nation for agricultural production, an industry that contributes over $50 billion annually to the economy. A diverse and well-trained workforce is critical to the success of California's and the nation's agricultural industry.  

This project will create seamless 2+2+2 pathways from high school, to two-year community college, and to four-year institutions for students interested in pursuing an education in agriculture business and related fields. Students will work towards a certificate, Associate of Science degree, and/or transfer to a four-year college and university. High school students will take college-level classes through dual enrollment pathways, thereby giving them a head start to a college education. An intensive two-week Summer Academy in Agriculture Sciences and Technology will expose students to educational and career opportunities in agriculture. Taken together these various academic pathways underpin the intellectual merit of the project and its focus on improved recruitment, retention, completion, and success through excellent classroom instruction, academic counseling, dedicated tutorial services, modified curriculum/course rotation, and internship opportunities. Finally, improved course articulation with undergraduate institutions will allow students the opportunity to transfer to four-year programs in agriculture.

por.por_cntn:
The 2+2+2 pathways project titled, Developing Post-Secondary Education and Career Pathways in Agriculture Business and Technology for Under-Represented Minority Student Populations aimed to (1) motivate and inspire to explore education and careers in agriculture, (2) develop and enhance curriculum to provide skills to address workforce needs, and (3) improve access and accelerate completion to enable students to achieve their educational and career goals. Through partnerships with feeder high schools in the Madera Community College service area, 4-year universities, and industry partners, the project demonstrated the effect of these partnerships in raising student interest in education and careers in agriculture. A summer camp coordinated between partners in 2019 created an opportunity for 18 students and 4 instructors from service area high schools to visit California State University, Chico to tour the campus and the surrounding agricultural industry. From survey data collected from students following the summer camp, students reported increasing their knowledge and interest in agricultural careers and expanding their professional network with those who can help them find jobs in agricultural careers. The intellectual merit of the project will help rural, 2-year community colleges understand their role in convening multiple stakeholders in collaborating within an industry sector like agriculture to generate student interest in post-secondary education and careers to fill skills gaps in the workforce.

 

The project titled Developing Post-Secondary Education and Career Pathways in Agriculture Business and Technology for Under-Represented Minority Student Populations achieved the outcomes the project set out to achieve despite disruptions during the COVID-19 pandemic. Enrollment in agricultural business courses increased across the three-year grant period. For academic year 2017-18, the unduplicated headcount was 122 students compared to 173 in academic year 2019-20. Further the 173 students in the 2019-20 academic year prepared their student educational plans with a Madera Community College counselor. In 2019, a summer camp coordinated between Madera Community College, industry partners, and a 4-year university created an opportunity for 18 student participants and 4 instructors to tour the California State University, Chico and local agricultural employers. Students who participate in the tours reported they gained a greater understanding of education and careers in agriculture. Among the student participants in the program in academic year 2019-20, seven students were awarded travel awards and attended the NSF-ATE PI Conference in Washington, DC where they met Congressman Jim Costa and participated in various network events and presentations. At the end of the grant period, 10 students transferred to 4-year universities.  

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2024
Modified by: Justin T Garcia
